title: How You Can Use Oils to Nourish Your Hair

content: Essential oils have been used for thousands of years and are revered around the world for their numerous benefits. From medicinal to spiritual uses, essential oils offer multipurpose options for self-expression and usefulness. With the popularity of complementary and alternative medicine, many people are looking to incorporate more natural products into their lifestyle, skin, and hair routines.

Whether it is a useful option for hair growth is a common question I get from my patients. Most dermatologists have varying opinions regarding the use of essential oils, as it has the potential to cause skin irritation and allergic reactions. In 2007, the American Contact Dermatitis Society named fragrance as Allergen of the Year, to raise awareness.

Essential oils fall under the category of cosmeceuticals, which have no direct FDA supervision or regulation. The product’s specific formula has not been studied, so efficacy is not validated before reaching the shelves. There is also great variability in the products offered, including the concentration of oil, additional ingredients, and different types of carrier oils used. While I typically do not recommend it for skin application due to the potential for significant irritation and allergic reactions, I believe this can be a safe option for applying to the scalp and hair. For this reason, I try to provide as much guidance, including specific product recommendations for patients who desire alternate treatments.

content: Much of essential oils' benefits on healthy hair have been documented in small studies, although they are stacking up to be a promising alternative. A 2015 study compared the effects of rosemary oil to minoxidil 2%. Another study showed after just 4 weeks, 3% and 5% lavender oil can delay the body’s natural hair-shedding cycle.

Additionally, carrier oils, like castor, argan, and coconut oils, are widely used for their presumptive hair growth and strengthening properties. The use of these products is also culturally rooted, often in Ayurveda and African practices.
Coconut oil was shown to improve brittle hair. This can be applied as a pre-shampoo treatment or as a mask to allow longer penetration.

sections.heading: Hair strengthening
content: Helpful tips for using essential oils

While there are some great over-the-counter options to start, I recommend visiting a board-certified dermatologist to discuss customized plans for your hair loss needs. Typically, natural alternatives are helpful to use alongside validated and tested medications to effectively treat hair loss.
Photo Credit: Prostock-Studio / iStock via Getty Images Plus
bullets: Make sure to mix with a carrier oil, like coconut or grape seed oil, to decrease the risk of irritation from direct essential oil contact with your skin.
Do not apply to your scalp more than twice daily.
If you develop a stinging or burning sensation, rinse out immediately and seek medical attention.
